newsitem.title: USA: New York opens hot line to report street crime.
newsitem.headline: New York opens hot line to report street crime.

text.p: In the campaign to stop so-called quality-of-life crimes, New York officials on Friday opened a new hotline for citizens to report panhandlers, prostitutes and "squeegee men" seen on the city's streets.
Officials have attributed the lowest crime rates in years to the quality-of-life strategy, which is based on the belief that many people who commit minor offences go on to perpetrate major crimes.

The "squeegee men" -- who approach cars stopped at intersections and wash windscreens with rubber implements known as "squeegees" in expectations of a tip -- were top of the target list released by police on Friday.

Police asked residents to call the new 24-hour toll-free hotline 1-888-677-LIFE to also report "aggressive panhandlers, loiterers at Automatic Teller Machines, illegal dumping, people creating permanent living spaces in public, street prostitution and any other non-emergency situation condition which contributes to a negative quality of life in the City."
For shootings, robberies and other emergencies, New Yorkers will still call 911.
Serious crime in New York was down 40 percent, in part because of the emphasis on stopping minor infractions, according to police department statistics.
But police commanders in the city's five boroughs were recently shown videotapes demonstrating that public drinking, public urination, subway fare-beating and panhandling persist.

Police Commissioner Howard Safir said the information gathered from the calls to the new hotline would be recorded, analysed and sent to each of the commanders to "develop strategies to permanently correct problem areas."
